whatIsIt.description: True/False/Not Given (T/F/NG) is one of the most common and challenging question types in the IELTS Academic and General Training Reading tests. You are given a series of statements and must decide whether each one agrees with, contradicts, or is not mentioned in the passage.
whatIsIt.skillTested: Distinguishing between stated, contradicted, and missing information with precision.

howToIdentify: Questions are factual statements about the passage
Appears in nearly every IELTS Reading test

example.passage: The honey bee population has declined by 30% over the past decade due to pesticide use and habitat loss. Scientists at Cambridge University have been studying this phenomenon since 2018. While some farmers have switched to organic methods, the majority still rely heavily on chemical pesticides. Research suggests that urban beekeeping programs could help stabilize bee populations in cities.

questions.text: Honey bee numbers have fallen by 30% in the last ten years.
questions.explanation: The passage directly states 'declined by 30% over the past decade.'
The text says 'since 2018,' meaning the research started in 2018, not before.

questions.text: Most farmers now use organic farming methods.
questions.explanation: The passage states 'the majority still rely heavily on chemical pesticides,' contradicting the statement.

questions.text: Urban beekeeping can completely solve the bee population crisis.
questions.explanation: The passage says it 'could help stabilize' but doesn't claim it will completely solve the crisis.

strategyTips.title: Read the Statement Carefully
strategyTips.description: Identify the KEY CLAIM being made. Note specific details: names, numbers, dates, qualifiers. Underline critical words.

strategyTips.title: Locate the Relevant Section
strategyTips.description: Statements usually follow passage order. Scan for keywords or synonyms. Find the 1-3 sentences that discuss this topic.

strategyTips.title: Compare Precisely
strategyTips.description: Read the relevant passage section carefully. Compare each element against the passage. Pay attention to qualifiers, scope, degree, and time references.

strategyTips.title: Apply the Three-Way Test
strategyTips.description: Can I find text that CONFIRMS this? → TRUE | Can I find text that CONTRADICTS this? → FALSE | Can I find NO relevant information? → NOT GIVEN

strategyTips.title: Verify Your Answer
strategyTips.description: For TRUE: Can I quote supporting evidence? For FALSE: Can I quote contradicting evidence? For NOT GIVEN: Am I certain this isn't addressed anywhere?

commonMistakes.title: Confusing FALSE with NOT GIVEN
commonMistakes.description: FALSE means the passage contradicts the statement. NOT GIVEN means no relevant information exists. Partial or missing information means NOT GIVEN, not FALSE.

commonMistakes.title: Using logic or outside knowledge
commonMistakes.description: Only rely on what's explicitly in the passage. Don't use common sense, assumptions, or what you think should be true.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring qualifying words
commonMistakes.description: Words like 'most,' 'some,' 'all,' 'often,' 'always' can completely change the meaning. 'Most students' is NOT the same as 'all students.'

commonMistakes.title: Expecting exact matches
commonMistakes.description: IELTS uses paraphrases; the wording will differ from the passage. Look for meaning, not word-for-word matches.

trapPatterns.description: Watch for misleading statements and distractors.
examples: Statements that are true in real life but not mentioned in the passage
Numbers or facts that are almost—but not exactly—the same
Information appearing in a different context
Extreme language (always, never, all) when passage uses qualified language
trapPatterns.warningSigns: Absolute terms like 'always,' 'never,' or 'all' often indicate FALSE answers when the passage uses more nuanced language.

difficultyPatterns: Earlier questions usually follow passage order; later ones may not
If you find info for one statement, nearby questions might be related
advancedTips.confidenceBooster: Information for TRUE and FALSE answers will always be clearly stated or clearly contradicted. If you're unsure, it's likely NOT GIVEN.

timeManagement.tip: If you're stuck on one question for more than 90 seconds, make your best guess, mark it for review, and move on. NOT GIVEN is statistically common.

quiz.passage: Online learning has transformed education dramatically over the past five years. A 2023 study by the Education Research Institute found that 78% of university students now take at least one online course during their degree. The flexibility of online learning appeals particularly to working adults, who represent 45% of all online learners. However, critics argue that online education lacks the social interaction necessary for developing communication skills. Professor Sarah Chen from Melbourne University believes that blended learning - combining online and face-to-face instruction - offers the best solution. She conducted research with 200 students in 2022 and found that those in blended programs showed 25% better engagement scores compared to purely online courses. Despite these benefits, technical difficulties remain a significant challenge, with 30% of students reporting connectivity issues during live sessions.

questions.text: What is the main difference between FALSE and NOT GIVEN answers?
options: FALSE means the information is wrong; NOT GIVEN means you disagree with it
FALSE means the passage contradicts the statement; NOT GIVEN means no relevant information is provided
FALSE means the information is incomplete; NOT GIVEN means it's too difficult to understand
There is no difference - they mean the same thing
questions.correctAnswer: FALSE means the passage contradicts the statement; NOT GIVEN means no relevant information is provided
questions.explanation: FALSE means the passage directly contradicts the statement, while NOT GIVEN means no relevant information exists in the passage.

questions.text: When looking for answers in the passage, you should:
options: Search for the exact same words as in the question
Look for synonyms and paraphrased information
Use your general knowledge if you can't find the information
Always read the entire passage first
questions.correctAnswer: Look for synonyms and paraphrased information
questions.explanation: IELTS tests your ability to identify paraphrased information, not exact word matching.

questions.text: If a statement says 'All teenagers use social media' but the passage says 'Most teenagers use social media,' the answer is:
options: TRUE - because most means almost all
FALSE - because 'all' and 'most' have different meanings
NOT GIVEN - because the exact percentage isn't provided
TRUE - because it's generally correct information
questions.correctAnswer: FALSE - because 'all' and 'most' have different meanings
questions.explanation: Qualifying words like 'all' vs 'most' change the meaning completely, making the statement false.

questions.text: Which time management strategy is recommended for T/F/NG questions?
options: Spend 3-5 minutes per question to be thorough
Read the entire passage before looking at any questions
Spend 60-90 seconds per question
Answer all TRUE answers first, then FALSE, then NOT GIVEN
questions.explanation: Efficient time management allows 60-90 seconds per T/F/NG question.

questions.text: More than three-quarters of university students take online courses.
questions.explanation: The passage states 78% of university students take online courses, which is more than three-quarters (75%).

questions.text: Working adults make up nearly half of all online learners.
questions.explanation: The passage states working adults represent 45% of all online learners, which is nearly half.

questions.text: Online education is inferior to traditional classroom learning.
questions.explanation: Critics argue about social interaction issues, but the passage doesn't state that online education is inferior overall.

questions.text: Professor Chen's research was conducted at Melbourne University.
questions.explanation: We know Professor Chen is from Melbourne University, but the passage doesn't specify where her research was conducted.

questions.text: Blended learning students had 25% higher grades than online-only students.
questions.explanation: The research found 25% better engagement scores, not higher grades.

questions.text: One-third of students experience technical problems during online classes.
questions.explanation: 30% of students report connectivity issues, which is less than one-third (33.3%).

do: Read the statement carefully before searching the text
Accept partial matches for TRUE answers
dont: Spend more than 2 minutes on one question
Choose FALSE just because you can’t find the words

subsections.title: 1.1 Overview
subsections.content: True/False/Not Given (T/F/NG) is one of the most common and challenging question types in the IELTS Academic and General Training Reading tests. You are given a series of statements and must decide whether each one agrees with, contradicts, or is not mentioned in the passage.

answerMeanings.meaning: The statement agrees with the information in the passage
The statement contradicts the information in the passage
There is no information about this in the passage

importantNote.title: Important Note
importantNote.description: In some IELTS tests, you'll see 'Yes/No/Not Given' instead. The difference:
importantNote.note: The strategy for both is essentially the same.

subsections.title: 1.2 What This Question Type Tests
subsections.description: T/F/NG questions assess several critical reading skills:

skills.meaning: Understanding specific information, not just general ideas
Recognizing when the same meaning is expressed differently
Knowing what the text actually says vs. what you assume
Paying attention to qualifiers, negatives, and scope

subsections.keyInsight: This question type does NOT test your opinion or general knowledge. It ONLY tests whether information appears in the passage and whether the statement matches it.

subsections.title: 2.1 TRUE — The Statement Agrees
criteria: The passage explicitly states the same information (possibly using different words)
The statement is a valid paraphrase of passage content
You can point to specific text that confirms the statement

example.passage: The research team discovered that dolphins can recognize themselves in mirrors, a capability previously thought to exist only in great apes and humans.
example.statement: Before this research, scientists believed only great apes and humans could identify their own reflection.
example.explanation: The statement paraphrases 'capability previously thought to exist only in great apes and humans.' The meaning is identical.

subsections.title: 2.2 FALSE — The Statement Contradicts
criteria: The passage states the OPPOSITE of what the statement claims
There is a direct, demonstrable contradiction
You can quote text that conflicts with the statement
subsections.criticalPoint: FALSE requires contradiction, not just absence. The passage must say something incompatible with the statement.

example.passage: The survey revealed that 68% of respondents preferred working from home at least three days per week.
example.statement: The majority of people surveyed wanted to work in the office most of the week.
example.explanation: 68% preferred working from home at least three days directly contradicts 'wanted to work in the office most of the week.' These cannot both be true.

subsections.title: 2.3 NOT GIVEN — No Information
subsections.description: The answer is NOT GIVEN when:
criteria: The passage does not mention this specific information at all
The topic might be related, but the specific claim is never addressed
You cannot find evidence to confirm OR deny the statement
subsections.criticalPoint: NOT GIVEN means absence of information. You cannot infer, assume, or use logic to determine the answer—the passage simply doesn't discuss it.

example.passage: The research team discovered that dolphins can recognize themselves in mirrors. The study was conducted at a marine facility in California over a period of two years.
example.statement: The research was funded by the US government.
example.explanation: The passage mentions where and how long the study took place, but says nothing about funding. We cannot assume anything about funding sources.

sections.title: SECTION 3: THE KEY DISTINCTION — FALSE vs. NOT GIVEN
sections.intro: This is where most students lose marks. Understanding this distinction is crucial.

FALSE: The passage ADDRESSES the topic and says the OPPOSITE
There IS information, but it CONTRADICTS
NOT GIVEN: The passage does NOT ADDRESS this specific point
There is NO information to judge

subsections.title: 3.2 The Two-Question Test
subsections.description: Ask yourself these two questions in order:

flowchart.question: Does the passage discuss this topic/make a related claim?
Does the passage AGREE or CONTRADICT?

subsections.title: 3.3 Comparison Examples
subsections.passage: The company was founded in Manchester in 1987 by two university graduates.

examples.statement: The company was established in London.

examples.reasoning: They were 'university graduates' but passage doesn't say they met there
No information about early financial situation

examples.statement: The company was founded by three people.

steps.title: Read the Statement Carefully
actions: Identify the KEY CLAIM being made
Note specific details: names, numbers, dates, qualifiers

steps.title: Locate the Relevant Section
actions: Statements usually follow passage order (Q1 → early paragraphs, Q5 → later paragraphs)
Scan for keywords or synonyms from the statement
Find the 1-3 sentences that discuss this topic

steps.title: Compare Precisely
actions: Read the relevant passage section carefully
Compare each element of the statement against the passage
Pay attention to: qualifiers, scope, degree, time references

steps.title: Apply the Three-Way Test
tests: Can I find text that CONFIRMS this? → TRUE
Can I find text that CONTRADICTS this? → FALSE
Can I find NO relevant information? → NOT GIVEN

steps.title: Verify Your Answer
checks: For TRUE: Can I quote supporting evidence?
For FALSE: Can I quote contradicting evidence?
For NOT GIVEN: Am I certain this isn't addressed anywhere?

subsections.title: 4.2 Time Management
subsections.tip: If you're stuck on one question for more than 90 seconds, make your best guess, mark it for review, and move on.

examples.answer: Could be TRUE (largest is also 'one of')

signalWords.description: Critical words that can change the answer completely

commonPitfalls.title: Common Mistakes & Pitfalls
commonPitfalls.description: The 10 Most Common Errors Students Make

mistakes.title: Using Outside Knowledge
mistakes.trap: You know something is true in real life, so you mark it TRUE.

example.passage: Passage discusses climate change but doesn't mention CO2.
example.statement: Carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas.
example.wrongThinking: I know CO2 is a greenhouse gas, so TRUE.
example.correctThinking: The passage doesn't mention CO2 at all → NOT GIVEN

mistakes.rule: Only use information IN the passage. Your knowledge is irrelevant.

mistakes.title: Confusing FALSE and NOT GIVEN
mistakes.trap: The statement seems wrong, so you choose FALSE—but the passage never discusses it.

example.passage: The experiment used 50 participants over three months.
example.statement: The experiment was expensive to conduct.
example.wrongThinking: 50 participants sounds expensive, but the passage doesn't say it was expensive, so FALSE.
example.correctThinking: Cost is never mentioned → NOT GIVEN

mistakes.rule: FALSE needs a contradiction. No information = NOT GIVEN.

mistakes.title: Over-Inferencing for TRUE
mistakes.trap: You make a logical assumption and treat it as confirmed.

example.passage: The CEO announced the company would expand into Asian markets.
example.statement: The company expects expansion to be profitable.
example.wrongThinking: Why would they expand if not for profit? TRUE.
example.correctThinking: Profitability expectations are never stated → NOT GIVEN

mistakes.rule: TRUE requires explicit support, not logical assumptions.

mistakes.title: Missing Paraphrases
mistakes.trap: You don't recognize that the passage says the same thing differently.

example.passage: The population declined rapidly.
example.statement: The number of inhabitants fell quickly.
example.wrongThinking: I can't find the words 'inhabitants' or 'fell' → NOT GIVEN.

mistakes.rule: Learn to recognize synonyms and paraphrases.

mistakes.title: Ignoring Qualifiers
mistakes.trap: You miss small words that change meaning significantly.

mistakes.title: Reversing Comparisons
mistakes.trap: You confuse which item is greater/lesser/earlier/later.

example.passage: Method A was more effective than Method B.
example.statement: Method B produced better results than Method A.
example.wrongThinking: It's comparing the two methods, so TRUE.
example.correctThinking: The passage says A > B, but statement says B > A → FALSE

mistakes.title: Scope Errors
mistakes.trap: The statement makes a broader or narrower claim than the passage.

example.passage: The study found that children who read daily performed better in school.
example.statement: Reading daily improves academic performance for all age groups.
example.correctThinking: Passage is about children only; statement claims ALL age groups → NOT GIVEN

mistakes.title: Partial Matches
mistakes.trap: Part of the statement is true, but another part is false or unconfirmed.

example.passage: Dr. Smith, a biologist from Oxford, published the findings in 2020.
example.statement: Dr. Smith, a chemist from Oxford, published the findings in 2020.
example.reasoning: One contradiction makes the whole statement false

mistakes.rule: Every part of the statement must be verified. One wrong element = FALSE.

mistakes.title: Misreading Negatives
mistakes.trap: Double negatives or negative constructions confuse you.

mistakes.title: Position Assumption
mistakes.trap: You assume statements at the end of the question set relate to the end of the passage.
mistakes.reality: While questions generally follow passage order, this isn't guaranteed. Always verify the location.
mistakes.strategy: Use keywords to locate the relevant section, don't rely on position alone.

questionTypes.name: Matching Headings
questionTypes.frequency: High - appears in approximately 60-70% of IELTS Reading tests

identifiers: A list of headings (usually labeled i, ii, iii, iv, etc.)
Instructions say 'Choose the correct heading for each paragraph/section'

subsections.title: 1.1 Overview
subsections.content: In this task, you are given a list of headings (marked with Roman numerals: i, ii, iii, iv...) and a text divided into sections or paragraphs (marked A, B, C...). Your task is to choose the heading that best reflects the main idea of each paragraph. There will always be more headings than paragraphs. This means some headings are 'distractors' that you will not use.

subsections.title: 1.2 What This Question Type Tests
subsections.description: Matching Headings assesses your ability to distinguish the 'Gist' (the overall meaning) from specific details.

skills.meaning: Reading quickly to understand the general theme
Finding the core message of a block of text
Telling the difference between a main point and a supporting example
Recognizing that the heading summarizes the text using different words

subsections.keyInsight: This is arguably the most difficult reading task because you cannot simply look for keywords. You must understand the purpose of the paragraph.

subsections.title: 2.1 The Role of a Heading
subsections.content: A correct heading acts like a Title. It must cover the content of the entire paragraph, not just one sentence within it.

example.heading: The financial cost of space travel
example.requirement: The Paragraph must discuss money, budget, or expenses throughout the majority of the text

subsections.title: 2.2 The Role of Distractors
subsections.content: The extra headings are not random. They are designed to trick you.
criteria: The Detail Distractor: A heading that covers only one specific sentence or example in the paragraph, but not the main idea
The Keyword Distractor: A heading that contains a specific word found in the text, but the meaning does not match

sections.title: SECTION 3: THE KEY DISTINCTION — MAIN IDEA vs. SUPPORTING DETAIL
sections.intro: This is where most students lose marks. You must learn to ignore details when looking for the main idea.

Main Idea: The writer's primary argument or topic
Supporting Detail: Statistics, names, dates, or examples used to prove the main idea

subsections.title: 3.2 The Scope Test
subsections.content: When you think you have found the right heading, ask yourself: 'Does this heading cover 80% of the paragraph, or only 20%?'

subsections.title: 3.3 Comparison Example
subsections.passage: While solar power is becoming cheaper, the initial installation cost remains a barrier for many households. Homeowners must pay thousands of dollars upfront for panels and batteries. Although government subsidies exist, they often do not cover the full expense, making solar energy a luxury for the wealthy.

examples.heading: The declining price of technology
examples.analysis: Detail - mentioned in the first clause only

examples.heading: Financial obstacles to adopting solar power
examples.analysis: Main Idea - covers the whole paragraph

steps.title: Analyze the Headings First
actions: Read the list of headings before the text
Try to identify the difference between similar headings

steps.title: Read Paragraph A (Topic Sentences)
actions: Read the first two sentences and the last sentence of the paragraph
The main idea is often located here
Warning: If the paragraph starts with a story or example, the main idea is likely in the middle

steps.title: Create Your Own Title
actions: Before looking back at the list, ask yourself: 'In three words, what was this paragraph about?'

steps.title: Match and Eliminate
actions: Look for the heading that matches your summary
If you find a match, write it down and cross it off the list
If unsure between two headings, write both (e.g., A = iv / vi) and move on

subsections.title: 4.2 Signal Words to Watch
subsections.content: Writers use specific words to signal the main idea.

categories.rule: The main idea is usually after these words
categories.example: Many people think X. However, the reality is Y. → The main idea is Y

categories.category: Conclusion Words (Therefore, Thus, As a result)
categories.rule: These usually summarize the main point

subsections.title: Passage Excerpt
subsections.passage: For centuries, the construction of bridges involved locally sourced materials such as wood and stone. These materials were abundant and cheap, but they limited the span and durability of the structures. Wooden bridges would rot, and stone bridges were difficult to build over deep water. It wasn't until the Industrial Revolution brought iron and steel that engineers could span great distances.
headings: i. The environmental impact of bridges
ii. Why modern bridges are superior
iii. Limitations of early building materials
subsections.question: Which heading matches Paragraph A?

examples.heading: i. Environmental impact
examples.analysis: NOT GIVEN. The text mentions materials, but not their impact on nature

examples.heading: iv. Industrial Revolution
examples.analysis: TRAP. It is mentioned in the last sentence, but it is not what the whole paragraph is about

examples.heading: ii. Modern bridges superior
examples.analysis: CLOSE. It implies modern materials are better, but the focus is on the past

examples.heading: iii. Limitations of early materials
examples.analysis: CORRECT. The paragraph lists wood and stone (early materials) and explains why they were bad (limited span, rot, hard to build)

commonPitfalls.title: Common Mistakes & Pitfalls
commonPitfalls.description: The 8 Most Common Errors Students Make

mistakes.title: Matching Keywords (The 'Word Spot' Trap)
mistakes.trap: You see the word 'Volcano' in the text and 'Volcanic' in the heading, so you match them immediately.
mistakes.rule: Read the sentence containing the word. Does the heading describe the whole paragraph or just that one word? Usually, exact word matches are traps.

mistakes.title: Reading Only the First Sentence
mistakes.trap: You rely 100% on the first sentence.
mistakes.rule: While often true, the main idea can be in the second sentence (especially if the first sentence is a 'hook' or a rhetorical question). Always check the middle and end.

mistakes.title: Spending Too Much Time on One Paragraph
mistakes.trap: You spend 5 minutes staring at Paragraph B because you can't decide.
mistakes.rule: If you are stuck, leave it. Do the easier paragraphs first. When you come back, you will have fewer headings to choose from.

mistakes.title: Not Crossing Out Used Headings
mistakes.trap: You keep re-reading the full list of headings for every single paragraph.
mistakes.rule: Eliminate headings as you go. This saves mental energy and reduces confusion.

mistakes.title: Confusing Examples with Main Points
mistakes.trap: The paragraph tells a story about a specific farmer. You choose a heading about 'Farming methods.'
mistakes.rule: The farmer is just an example. What point is the writer proving by using the farmer?

mistakes.title: Ignoring Distractors
mistakes.trap: You forget that there are 2-3 extra headings that you will not use.
mistakes.rule: Do not force a heading to fit just because it's left over. It might be a distractor.

mistakes.title: Looking for Specific Details
mistakes.trap: You treat this like a 'Gap Fill' question, looking for names and dates.
mistakes.rule: Switch your brain to 'Summary Mode.' You are looking for general themes, not specific data points.

mistakes.title: Ignoring Plurals
mistakes.trap: The heading says 'The causes of poverty' (Plural). The paragraph discusses only one cause.
mistakes.rule: If the heading is plural, the paragraph must list more than one factor. If it only lists one, that heading is wrong.

questionTypes.name: Multiple Choice
questionTypes.frequency: High - appears in almost every IELTS Reading test

quickStartGuide.title: 5 Essential Rules - Master These First
essentials: Read the question BEFORE looking at the options
Eliminate obviously wrong answers first (process of elimination)
Don't choose based on word matching - look for paraphrases
Find specific evidence in the passage to support your choice
Beware of 'true but irrelevant' options - they must ANSWER the question
quickStartGuide.commonTrap: The most common mistake: choosing an answer just because it uses the same words as the passage, even though it doesn't answer the question or has a different meaning.

identifiers: Question followed by 3-4 options (A, B, C, D)
Instructions say 'Choose the correct letter' or 'Choose TWO/THREE letters'
Can ask about main ideas, details, writer's opinion, or purpose
variants: Single answer questions (choose ONE letter) - most common
Multiple answer questions (choose TWO or THREE letters) - harder, all-or-nothing scoring

whatIsIt.description: Multiple choice questions test various reading skills by asking you to select the correct answer from 3-4 options. Questions can focus on specific details, main ideas, writer's purpose, attitude, or implied meaning.
whatIsIt.skillTested: Your ability to understand specific details, main ideas, writer's purpose, attitude, or opinion
whatIsIt.howItWorks: You read a question and choose the correct answer from 3-4 options. Some questions require selecting multiple answers (e.g., 'Choose TWO letters').
whatIsIt.scoringImpact: Typically 3-7 questions per passage, worth 1 point each. CRITICAL: For 'choose TWO/THREE' questions, you must get ALL answers correct to earn the point - no partial credit.

example.passage: Research shows that regular exercise improves not only physical health but also mental well-being. Studies indicate that just 30 minutes of moderate activity daily can reduce anxiety and depression symptoms by up to 40%. However, many people struggle to maintain consistent exercise routines due to time constraints and lack of motivation.

questions.text: According to the passage, what is the main benefit of exercise?
options: A. It only improves physical health
B. It improves both physical and mental health
C. It requires expensive equipment
D. It takes several hours per day
questions.explanation: The passage states exercise improves "not only physical health but also mental well-being"

questionTypes.whatToLookFor: Specific facts, dates, names, numbers clearly stated in the text
questionTypes.strategy: Scan for keywords, find the exact location, read carefully for paraphrases

signals: The primary focus of the paragraph is...
questionTypes.whatToLookFor: Overall theme or central point of the passage or paragraph
questionTypes.strategy: Read topic sentences and conclusions, ignore specific details

signals: What does the author mean by...
questionTypes.whatToLookFor: Meaning that is suggested but not directly stated - read between the lines
questionTypes.strategy: Look for clues in context, tone, and logical connections

signals: The writer's tone can be described as...
questionTypes.whatToLookFor: Language that shows the writer's viewpoint, feelings, or judgment
questionTypes.strategy: Identify attitude indicators - adjectives, adverbs, and evaluative language

signals: The purpose of paragraph X is...
The writer includes this example to...
questionTypes.whatToLookFor: Why the writer included certain information or examples - function rather than content
questionTypes.strategy: Think about how the information connects to the main argument

signals: What does the word '...' mean in line X?
questionTypes.whatToLookFor: Meaning of a word or phrase based on how it's used in the passage
questionTypes.strategy: Read the sentence before and after, try substituting each option

critical.example: The study merely examines surface issues

paraphrasingPatterns.description: IELTS always paraphrases information. The correct answer rarely uses the exact same words as the passage.

optionExamples: The discovery of a new species occurred

commonPatterns.passageExample: Due to budget cuts, the program was cancelled
optionExamples: Budget cuts led to program cancellation
The program ended because of funding issues

detailQuestion.passage: The sharing economy has fundamentally altered consumer behavior in urban centers. Apps like Uber and Airbnb have made it possible to access services without ownership, appealing particularly to younger generations who value experiences over possessions.
detailQuestion.question: What is the main advantage of the sharing economy mentioned in the passage?
options: A. It provides stable employment
B. It allows access to services without ownership
C. It increases worker benefits
D. It reduces company profits
detailQuestion.thinkingProcess: This is a DETAIL question ('What is mentioned'). Scan for keywords: 'advantage' or 'benefit'. The passage says apps 'made it possible to access services without ownership' - this directly matches option B.

eliminationProcess.A: WRONG - Nothing about employment is mentioned as an advantage
eliminationProcess.B: CORRECT - Directly stated: 'access services without ownership'
eliminationProcess.C: WRONG - Worker benefits are not mentioned
eliminationProcess.D: WRONG - Company profits are not discussed

detailQuestion.explanation: The passage explicitly states the sharing economy makes it 'possible to access services without ownership' - this is a paraphrase match with option B.

inferenceQuestion.passage: Critics argue that online education lacks the social interaction necessary for developing communication skills. Professor Sarah Chen believes that blended learning - combining online and face-to-face instruction - offers the best solution. She conducted research with 200 students in 2022 and found that those in blended programs showed 25% better engagement scores compared to purely online courses.
inferenceQuestion.question: What can be inferred about Professor Chen's view on purely online courses?
options: A. They are completely ineffective for learning
B. They have some limitations compared to blended learning
C. They should be banned from universities
D. They are more expensive than traditional courses
inferenceQuestion.thinkingProcess: This is an INFERENCE question ('can be inferred'). Professor Chen's research showed blended learning had better results than purely online. This suggests online-only has weaknesses, but she doesn't say it's completely bad.

eliminationProcess.A: WRONG - Too extreme. She doesn't say purely online is 'completely ineffective', just that blended is better
eliminationProcess.B: CORRECT - She shows blended is better (25% higher engagement), implying online-only has limitations
eliminationProcess.C: WRONG - Extreme and not suggested anywhere

inferenceQuestion.explanation: Since her research shows blended learning performs better, we can infer she believes purely online has limitations. Option B is carefully worded to match this inference without being too extreme.

opinionQuestion.passage: The proposal to build a new highway through the forest has sparked considerable debate. Environmentalists have raised alarming concerns about habitat destruction and increased carbon emissions. While the government claims economic benefits will outweigh environmental costs, this argument fails to consider the long-term ecological damage that could prove irreversible.
opinionQuestion.question: What is the writer's attitude toward the highway proposal?
options: A. Strongly supportive
B. Completely neutral
C. Somewhat skeptical
D. Mildly optimistic
opinionQuestion.thinkingProcess: This is an OPINION/ATTITUDE question. Look for evaluative language. The writer uses 'alarming concerns', says the government's argument 'fails to consider', and mentions 'irreversible' damage. This shows skepticism/doubt.

eliminationProcess.A: WRONG - The writer criticizes the proposal, not supports it
eliminationProcess.B: WRONG - The language is clearly not neutral ('alarming', 'fails to consider')
eliminationProcess.C: CORRECT - Words like 'fails to consider' and 'irreversible' show doubt/skepticism
eliminationProcess.D: WRONG - Nothing suggests optimism; the tone is critical

opinionQuestion.explanation: The writer's use of critical language ('fails to consider', 'alarming', 'irreversible') indicates skepticism about the proposal.

purposeQuestion.passage: Renewable energy costs have dropped dramatically. Solar panel prices, for instance, have fallen by 90% since 2010. This price revolution has made clean energy accessible to millions of households worldwide who previously could not afford it.
purposeQuestion.question: Why does the writer mention solar panel prices?
options: A. To criticize the solar industry
B. To provide an example of falling renewable energy costs
C. To argue that solar is better than wind power
D. To explain how solar panels work
purposeQuestion.thinkingProcess: This is a PURPOSE question ('Why does the writer mention...'). The first sentence says renewable energy costs dropped. Then 'for instance' introduces solar panels as a specific EXAMPLE of this general point.

eliminationProcess.A: WRONG - The tone is positive, not critical
eliminationProcess.B: CORRECT - 'For instance' signals that solar panels are an example of the previous statement about falling costs
eliminationProcess.C: WRONG - Wind power is not mentioned or compared
eliminationProcess.D: WRONG - How they work is not explained

purposeQuestion.explanation: The phrase 'for instance' clearly signals that solar panels are being used as a specific example to illustrate the general statement about falling renewable energy costs.

multipleAnswerQuestions.scoringRule: ❗ CRITICAL: Must get ALL answers correct for 1 point - no partial credit. If you choose 2 out of 3 correctly, you get 0 points.
multipleAnswerQuestions.howToRecognize: Instructions say 'Choose TWO letters' or 'Choose THREE letters'
strategy: Read the question carefully - it may ask for things, reasons, features, etc.
Look for options that are BOTH/ALL clearly and explicitly supported in the passage
Don't choose options that contradict each other
Check that the passage supports ALL your choices, not just one
Be conservative - only choose if you're certain

example.passage: Remote work has increased productivity for many employees, particularly those with long commutes. However, managers report difficulty in monitoring performance and maintaining team cohesion. Employee surveys show mixed feelings: while 78% appreciate flexibility, 45% report feeling isolated. Some companies have adopted hybrid models, requiring employees to attend the office 2-3 days per week to balance these concerns.
example.question: Which TWO problems with remote work are mentioned?
options: A. Decreased productivity
B. Difficulty supervising employees
C. Increased operational costs
D. Challenges maintaining team unity
E. Employee dissatisfaction with flexibility
example.thinkingProcess: Need to find TWO problems clearly stated. Look for negative aspects or challenges mentioned.

eliminationProcess.A: WRONG - Passage says productivity INCREASED, not decreased
eliminationProcess.B: CORRECT - 'managers report difficulty in monitoring performance' = supervision problems
eliminationProcess.C: WRONG - Operational costs are never mentioned
eliminationProcess.D: CORRECT - 'maintaining team cohesion' is explicitly mentioned as a difficulty
eliminationProcess.E: WRONG - 78% appreciate flexibility, so most are satisfied with it

example.explanation: Both B and D are explicitly stated as problems. B is paraphrased from 'difficulty in monitoring performance' and D from 'maintaining team cohesion'.
example.commonMistake: Students might choose A because it seems logical, but the passage actually says the OPPOSITE - productivity increased. Always base answers on what's stated, not logic.

subtleDifferences.description: Often two options will seem very similar. You must identify the subtle but important difference.

example1.passage: Most scientists agree that climate change is accelerating, though a small minority remain skeptical.
example1.question: What does the passage say about scientific opinion on climate change?
example1.optionA: All scientists believe climate change is speeding up
example1.optionB: The majority of scientists think climate change is accelerating
example1.keyDifference: 'Most' vs 'All' - this is a qualifying word trap
example1.explanation: Option A says 'all' but the passage says 'most' - these mean different things. Option B correctly paraphrases 'most' as 'majority' and 'accelerating' as 'speeding up'. Always check qualifying words carefully.

example2.passage: The study suggests that regular exercise may reduce the risk of heart disease.
example2.question: According to the passage, what is the relationship between exercise and heart disease?
example2.optionB: Exercise might lower heart disease risk
example2.explanation: Option A is too strong. The passage uses 'may reduce', which means possibility, not certainty. 'Prevents' implies it definitely stops it, but 'might lower risk' correctly captures the cautious tone.

example3.passage: Urban gardens provide fresh produce and strengthen community bonds.
example3.question: What benefit of urban gardens is mentioned?
example3.keyDifference: Both seem like benefits, but only A is actually stated
example3.explanation: 'Strengthen community bonds' is paraphrased as 'improve neighborhood relationships' in option A. Option B might be true in reality, but it's not mentioned in the passage - don't use general knowledge.

easy.characteristics: Direct fact stated clearly, minimal paraphrasing

example.passage: The research was conducted in 2022 with 500 participants.
example.question: How many people participated in the research?
options: D. Not stated
example.whyEasy: Number is explicitly stated with no paraphrasing

medium.characteristics: Fact is stated but paraphrased in options, requires careful reading

example.passage: The program has led to a 30% reduction in waste.
example.question: What impact has the program had?
options: A. Waste increased by 30%
B. Waste was eliminated completely
C. Waste decreased by nearly one-third
D. Waste stayed the same

hard.characteristics: Requires inference, understanding tone/purpose, or comparing subtle options

example.passage: While the technology shows promise, researchers caution that significant obstacles remain before commercial viability can be achieved.
example.question: What is the researchers' view of the technology?
options: A. It is ready for commercial use
B. It has potential but faces challenges
C. It should be abandoned
D. It is completely impractical
example.whyHard: Requires understanding the contrast between 'shows promise' (positive) and 'obstacles remain' (negative), then finding the balanced option that captures both aspects

commonMistakes.title: Word Matching Trap
commonMistakes.description: Choosing an option just because it contains the same words as the passage, even though the meaning is different or it doesn't answer the question

example.passage: The decline in bee populations is not caused by mobile phone radiation.
example.wrongChoice: Option: Mobile phone radiation affects bee populations
example.whyWrong: The passage mentions mobile phones, but says they do NOT cause the problem. Students see matching words and choose it.

commonMistakes.howToAvoid: Read the complete sentence in the passage AND the complete option. Check if the meaning actually matches.

commonMistakes.title: True But Irrelevant
commonMistakes.description: Selecting an answer that is stated in the passage but doesn't actually answer the specific question being asked

example.passage: Solar panels have become cheaper. However, installation costs remain high.
example.question: What problem is mentioned?
example.wrongChoice: Option: Solar panel prices have decreased
example.whyWrong: This is TRUE and stated in the passage, but the question asks for a PROBLEM. The problem is installation costs, not the price decrease.

commonMistakes.howToAvoid: Always check: does this option answer what the question is specifically asking?

commonMistakes.title: Using General Knowledge
commonMistakes.description: Choosing an answer that is true in general or from your knowledge, but is not stated or supported in the passage

example.passage: Electric cars produce zero emissions while driving.
example.question: What advantage is mentioned?
example.wrongChoice: Option: Electric cars are better for the environment overall
example.whyWrong: While this might be true, the passage only mentions zero emissions while driving, not overall environmental impact. Battery production etc. are not discussed.

commonMistakes.howToAvoid: Only choose answers that can be directly supported by the passage text. Ignore what you know from outside.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Qualifying Words
commonMistakes.description: Missing important words like 'some,' 'most,' 'usually' vs. 'always,' 'never,' 'all' that completely change the meaning

example.passage: Most experts recommend daily exercise.
example.wrongChoice: Option: All experts recommend daily exercise
example.whyWrong: 'Most' and 'all' mean different things. Most = majority, All = 100%

qualifyingWords.caution: Options with absolute words are often wrong unless the passage also uses absolute language

commonMistakes.howToAvoid: Circle qualifying words in both the question and options. Make sure they match.

commonMistakes.title: Not Reading All Options
commonMistakes.description: Selecting the first option that seems reasonable without comparing it to all other choices

example.scenario: Option B seems good, so student picks it without reading C and D. But option D is actually more accurate.
example.whyWrong: There might be a BETTER option that more precisely matches the passage

commonMistakes.howToAvoid: Read ALL options before choosing. Often option D is the most accurate.

commonMistakes.title: Choosing Partial Answers
commonMistakes.description: Selecting an option that is partially correct but includes one wrong detail

example.passage: The study examined 200 adults over 6 months.
example.wrongChoice: Option: The study examined 200 children over 6 months
example.whyWrong: Number and duration are correct, but 'children' should be 'adults' - one wrong word makes the whole answer wrong

commonMistakes.howToAvoid: Check that EVERY part of the option is supported by the passage. One wrong detail = wrong answer.

trapPatterns.description: Statement is in the passage but doesn't answer the question
trapPatterns.example: Question asks about advantages, but option mentions a disadvantage that is stated in the text
trapPatterns.redFlag: The option seems familiar from the passage but doesn't match what the question is asking

trapPatterns.description: Contains some correct information but includes a wrong detail
trapPatterns.example: Option says 'all workers' when passage says 'most workers'
trapPatterns.redFlag: Most of the option matches but one word seems different - check carefully

trapPatterns.description: Uses similar words but reverses the meaning
trapPatterns.redFlag: The words look familiar but the meaning feels backwards

trapPatterns.description: Uses absolute language when passage uses qualified language
trapPatterns.redFlag: Option uses words like 'always', 'never', 'all', 'none' when passage says 'often', 'sometimes', 'many', 'few'

trapPatterns.description: Uses a word that seems similar but has a different meaning
trapPatterns.redFlag: Similar words with different strengths - 'reduce' means lower, 'eliminate' means remove completely

trapPatterns.description: Uses information from the passage but in a different context
trapPatterns.example: Passage mentions cost in paragraph 1 about cars, option mentions cost but about housing
trapPatterns.redFlag: The information exists but is about something else

questionTypes.warningSign: ⚠️ If an answer seems too obvious or uses exact words from the passage, STOP and double-check it - it might be a word-matching trap. The correct answer usually paraphrases.

strategyTips.title: Read the question carefully FIRST
strategyTips.description: Identify what type of question it is (detail, main idea, inference, opinion, purpose) BEFORE looking at options
strategyTips.why: This focuses your reading and prevents option bias

strategyTips.title: Identify and underline keywords
strategyTips.description: Underline key words in the question - names, dates, specific terms, question focus
strategyTips.why: Helps you scan the passage efficiently

strategyTips.title: Scan for the relevant section
strategyTips.description: Questions usually follow passage order. Use keywords to locate where the answer will be
strategyTips.why: Saves time - you don't need to reread the entire passage

strategyTips.title: Read that section thoroughly
strategyTips.description: Don't just skim - read the relevant 2-3 sentences carefully, understanding the complete meaning
strategyTips.why: Skimming causes you to miss important details or misunderstand

strategyTips.title: Read ALL options before choosing
strategyTips.description: Even if option A seems good, read B, C, and D. One of them might be more precise
strategyTips.why: The best answer might come later in the list

strategyTips.title: Eliminate obviously wrong answers
strategyTips.description: Cross out options that are clearly incorrect, opposite, or not mentioned
strategyTips.why: Narrows down your choices and increases accuracy

strategyTips.title: Compare remaining options carefully
strategyTips.description: If stuck between two options, find the specific difference and check which the passage supports
strategyTips.why: Often the difference is one word - 'most' vs 'all', 'may' vs 'will'

strategyTips.title: Find specific evidence
strategyTips.description: Identify the exact sentence(s) in the passage that support your choice
strategyTips.why: Evidence-based selection is more reliable than 'gut feeling'

strategyTips.title: Check your answer matches the question
strategyTips.description: Reread the question and verify your answer actually answers what's being asked

keyTechniques.underlining: Underline key words in questions and options to stay focused on what matters
keyTechniques.qualifyingWords: Pay special attention to qualifying words: some/all, often/always, may/will, usually/never, most/every
keyTechniques.questionOrder: Questions usually follow passage order - use this to locate information quickly
keyTechniques.evidenceBased: Always find specific evidence in the passage to support your answer - don't rely on memory or feelings
keyTechniques.elimination: When stuck, eliminate what's definitely wrong rather than trying to find what's definitely right
keyTechniques.paraphraseRecognition: Train yourself to recognize synonyms and paraphrases - the correct answer rarely uses exact words

timeManagement.totalTime: 5-10 minutes for a set of 5-7 questions
timeManagement.tip: Don't spend more than 2 minutes on any single question. If stuck, eliminate what you can, make your best guess, and move on. You can return if time permits.

allocation.reading: 30-40 seconds - locate and read relevant section
allocation.analyzing: 30-40 seconds - read and compare all options

dos: ✅ Read the question BEFORE looking at options
✅ Identify the question type (detail, inference, opinion, etc.)
✅ Find specific evidence in the passage for your answer
✅ Pay attention to qualifying words (some, often, may, usually)
✅ Look for paraphrases, not exact word matches
✅ Check your answer actually answers the specific question
✅ Circle or underline key words to stay focused
✅ Use process of elimination when unsure
donts: ❌ Don't choose based on word matching alone
❌ Don't use your general knowledge instead of passage information
❌ Don't select the first option that seems reasonable without reading others
❌ Don't spend more than 2 minutes on one question
❌ Don't assume an answer is correct just because it's true
❌ Don't choose options with extreme words unless passage is also extreme
❌ Don't rely on memory - always check the passage
❌ Don't leave answers blank - always guess if running out of time
❌ Don't choose an option just because it sounds academic or complex

advancedTips.title: Difficulty Progression
advancedTips.description: Easy questions ask about clearly stated facts. Hard questions ask about implied meaning, purpose, or tone. Recognize which type you're facing.
advancedTips.application: If a question seems hard, it's likely testing inference or attitude - look for clues beyond literal statements

advancedTips.title: Question Order Pattern
advancedTips.description: Questions typically follow the order of information in the passage - use this to navigate efficiently
advancedTips.application: If Q1 answer is in paragraph 1 and Q3 is in paragraph 3, Q2 answer is probably in paragraph 2

advancedTips.title: Cross-Question Intelligence
advancedTips.description: Information you find for one question may help eliminate options in another question
advancedTips.application: If Q1 establishes that costs increased, any option in Q2 saying costs decreased must be wrong

advancedTips.title: Extreme Language Red Flag
advancedTips.description: Options with extreme words (always, never, all, none, only, every) are usually wrong unless the passage uses equally extreme language
advancedTips.application: If passage says 'most scientists', option saying 'all scientists' is probably wrong

advancedTips.title: Process Over Product
advancedTips.description: Sometimes it's easier to eliminate three wrong answers than to identify one correct answer directly
advancedTips.application: Use systematic elimination: cross out impossible → cross out extreme → cross out irrelevant → choose from remaining

advancedTips.title: First vs Last Strategy
advancedTips.description: Some students prefer answering easiest questions first to build confidence and save time
advancedTips.application: Quickly scan all questions, answer obvious ones first, then tackle harder ones with remaining time

advancedTips.title: Tone Words Matter
advancedTips.description: For opinion/attitude questions, one adjective can change everything

advancedTips.title: Example/Detail vs Main Point
advancedTips.description: Don't confuse examples or supporting details with the main point being made
advancedTips.application: If passage gives 3 examples of renewable energy, don't choose an option that only mentions solar panels (one example)

whenRunningOutOfTime: Quickly scan for keywords from the question in the passage
Read only that sentence and the one before/after it
Make your best guess from remaining options
NEVER leave blank - no penalty for wrong answers
guessing Strategy: If totally stuck, eliminate options with:
emergencyStrategy.confidenceBooster: Wrong answers usually have clear, identifiable reasons why they're wrong. Trust your elimination process - if you can eliminate 2-3 options, your guess has a good chance.

whatIsIt.description: These questions test your ability to find specific information and complete sentences with words from the passage. You must follow word limits (e.g., NO MORE THAN TWO WORDS).
whatIsIt.skillTested: Scanning for specific information and understanding context.

example.passage: The Amazon rainforest produces approximately 20% of the world's oxygen and is home to over 390 billion individual trees. Scientists estimate that one in ten known species in the world lives in the Amazon ecosystem.

questions.text: The Amazon rainforest generates about _____ of the planet's oxygen.
questions.explanation: The passage states "approximately 20% of the world's oxygen"

questions.text: There are more than _____ trees in the Amazon.
questions.explanation: The passage mentions "over 390 billion individual trees"

commonMistakes.title: Exceeding the word limit
commonMistakes.description: If it says NO MORE THAN TWO WORDS, you cannot write three words. You'll get zero marks even if the meaning is correct.

commonMistakes.title: Changing the form of words
commonMistakes.description: Use the EXACT words from the passage. Don't change singular to plural or verb tenses.

commonMistakes.title: Including unnecessary articles
commonMistakes.description: Don't write "the 390 billion" if the limit is two words. Write "390 billion" only.

commonMistakes.title: Poor spelling
commonMistakes.description: Copy the spelling exactly from the passage. Misspelled answers receive no marks.

strategyTips.title: Read the instruction carefully
strategyTips.description: Note the word limit (e.g., ONE WORD, TWO WORDS, THREE WORDS)

strategyTips.title: Identify keywords in the sentence
strategyTips.description: Find words that will help you locate the answer in the passage

strategyTips.title: Scan for the relevant section
strategyTips.description: Questions usually follow the order of the passage

strategyTips.title: Check grammar fits
strategyTips.description: Your answer must make the sentence grammatically correct

strategyTips.title: Copy exactly and count words
strategyTips.description: Use exact spelling and punctuation, verify word count

timeManagement.tip: These are usually quicker than other question types if you scan efficiently.

whatIsIt.description: These questions require you to answer with specific information from the passage, following strict word limits. Answers are usually factual details like names, dates, or numbers.
whatIsIt.skillTested: Precise scanning and extracting factual information.

example.passage: Marie Curie won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1903 and the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1911, making her the first person to win Nobel Prizes in two different sciences. She conducted her groundbreaking research on radioactivity in Paris.

questions.text: In which city did Marie Curie conduct her research? (NO MORE THAN ONE WORD)
questions.explanation: The passage states she conducted research "in Paris"

questions.text: When did Curie win her first Nobel Prize? (NO MORE THAN ONE WORD)
questions.explanation: The passage mentions "Nobel Prize in Physics in 1903"

commonMistakes.title: Writing complete sentences
commonMistakes.description: Short answers don't need full sentences. Just write the specific word(s) requested.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring word limits
commonMistakes.description: Stick to the word limit exactly. "NO MORE THAN TWO WORDS" means 1 or 2 words only.

commonMistakes.title: Not using words from the passage
commonMistakes.description: Your answer must come directly from the passage, not your own knowledge.

commonMistakes.title: Including extra information
commonMistakes.description: Only answer what is asked. Don't add extra details.

strategyTips.title: Identify the question word
strategyTips.description: What, where, when, who, how many - tells you what type of answer to find

strategyTips.title: Note the word limit
strategyTips.description: Check if it's one word, two words, or three words maximum

strategyTips.title: Scan for keywords
strategyTips.description: Find the relevant section quickly using key terms from the question

strategyTips.title: Extract the precise answer
strategyTips.description: Copy the answer exactly as it appears, don't paraphrase

strategyTips.title: Verify grammar and spelling
strategyTips.description: Make sure your answer is grammatically correct and spelled correctly

timeManagement.tip: Short answer questions should be quick. They test scanning ability, not reading comprehension.
